awd_titl_txt: RCN: Enabling comparative studies of the process and products of sexual selection in a genomic context
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Coordination Network facilitates new interdisciplinary research collaborations that will advance our understanding of the genomic underpinnings of evolutionary processes important in shaping the ecology, physiology, behavior and diversification of organisms. The network brings together pioneers in the application of genomic approaches, researchers with long-term ecological and behavioral data, software developers and information management specialists to enrich, share, and connect large-scale data sets that provide the foundation for tackling fundamental questions of how organismal traits evolve.  Products of this effort include an open-access data repository, a publically available genome browser, and a model of how diverse teams of scientists can collaborate to transform independent research across disciplines into a synthetic enterprise that will provide answers to significant biological questions.  

This Research Coordination Network is designed to address the evolutionary implications of sexual selection from the level of the genome, to physiology and behavior, to the ecosystem using manakins as a model system.  These birds inhabit tropical forests, exhibit extraordinary physical and behavioral adaptations and are readily amenable for study. The network unites researchers across many disciplines to engage in a community-wide effort to enrich genomic resources through functional annotation, develop mechanisms to connect related but heterogeneous data, and apply these resources to understand the complex relationships between genomes and environment that produce form and function in living organisms. The network operates through annual meetings, workshops, working groups, and lab exchanges to develop shared genomic resources, an open-access data repository, synthetic papers and proposals, and new educational and research tools.

por.por_cntn:
The unifying goal of this Research Coordination Network was to enable comparative studies of the process and products of sexual selection in a genomic context using a family of tropical birds as a model system. These birds, called manakins, offer exceptional opportunities to reveal the mechanisms underlying sexual selection because of their complex behavioral dance and courtship displays, brightly-colored plumages, and breeding system in which females assume all nesting and parental care for offspring, while males spend much of their lives perfecting elaborate courtship displays to attract females as mates.  To achieve our goals we brought together a diverse group of scientists that represented multiple disciplines (behavior, genetics/genomics, physiology, ecology, neurobiology/endocrinology, developmental biology, phylogenetics/systematics, bioinformatics), career stages, and professional experiences.  These scientists shared large and long-term data sets collected across many of the 50+ species in the family to facilitate new discoveries and insights.  In addition, over the course of this RCN, scientists from many labs worked together to sequence, assemble and annotate high-quality genomes from multiple species across the manakin clade, greatly adding to existing genomic resources. The project generated 7 high-quality whole genome assemblies and facilitated the development of many more genomic resources (transcriptomes, population genomic datasets, low-coverage genomes). All genome assemblies have been made available to the scientific community.   

Integrating these new genomic data and their products with behavioral, morphological, physiological and other information, this project has significantly advanced our ability to link genotype to phenotype in manakins, a challenge across biological systems.  Further, our ability to integrate across disciplines enabled studies and discoveries across multiple levels of organization (cells to organisms to populations to species to the entire manakin family).  Further, studies using genomic resources have resulted in first-ever comparisons of manakin traits, many of which are under sexual selection, across species revealing new insights about evolution in form and function.  For example, this project has discovered how unique adaptations in the neuroendocrine, anatomy, and physiology of male manakins have enabled the elaborate courtships displays, including dance, vocal and mechanical sounds, and contributed to the maintenance of social interactions.  Across manakin species, those species with more complex courtship displays (e.g., more acrobatic maneuvers, cooperative displays) had associated greater development of parts of the brain (e.g., cerebellum, sensorimotor arcopallium); these parts of the brain are known to play roles in sensorimotor processes and learning and performance of precisely timed and sequenced movements. The results from this project also have impact more broadly across systems.  We have found that candidate genes for the traits under sexual selection in manakins reveal general mechanisms for color polymorphisms and epidermal pattern development in groups far beyond birds.  In addition, this project has revealed the key role diet has played in providing opportunities for sexual selection to act.  It has furthermore shown how sexual selection can drive gene flow across species boundaries, creating evolutionary innovation and influencing diversification processes. The integrative approaches championed by this project link physiology, behavior, ecology, evolution and genomics and provide a conceptual and practical framework that advances collaborative team science and results in impactful research training. 

The broader impacts of this project have included opportunities for professional and career development for more than 60 graduate students and undergraduate students, 15-20 post-doctoral associates, and 10 early career faculty, many from under-represented groups.  Throughout the course of this project, undergraduate students were recruited into graduate programs, 8 PhD students completed their dissertations and moved into post-doctoral or faculty positions, and several early career faculty were promoted and received tenure.  The project contributed to training across disciplines through in-person facilitated workshops, webinars, lab exchanges, courses, and field training; these activities resulted in graduate students from ecology and behavioral backgrounds adding genomic components to their dissertation research.  The project also focused on developing skills to work across disciplines and cultures, and facilitate and empower collaborative team science.  Early career professionals were encouraged, supported and mentored to take leadership roles in team science activities, leading many of the joint products of this project.  We also capitalized on the collective diversity of this group to produce outreach materials for K-12 and the public, including local residents near our field sites, build on video and photographic collections for public and scientific use, including high-speed videos of male courtship displays, and tell the manakin story through public talks and the project website.
